working.translation[0].definitions[0].de: having a job that you are paid for
working.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Many working women rely on relatives for childcare.
A smaller working population will have to support a growing number of retired people.
working.translation[0].definitions[1].de: having a physical or practical job
working.translation[1].definitions[0].de: a mine or part of a mine where soil has been dug out in order to remove metals or stone
working.translation[2].definitions[0].de: working people have jobs that they are paid for
working.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: What will the effect of the tax changes be on working couples?
In the U.K., less than 3% of the working population are now employed in agriculture.
working.translation[2].definitions[1].de: a working man or woman does physical work, rather than work in management or administration
working.translation[2].definitions[2].de: working conditions or practices are ones that you have in your job
working.translation[2].definitions[2].ex: Workers want better pay and working conditions.
Productivity is up 18% since a new labor pact last year swept away decades-old working practices.
working.translation[2].definitions[3].de: your working day, week etc is the period of time when you are doing your job
working.translation[2].definitions[3].ex: Working hours are flexible here and the dress is casual.
We want a shorter working day.
working.translation[2].definitions[4].de: a breakfast, lunch etc that is also a business meeting
working.translation[2].definitions[5].de: to be working properly and not broken
working.translation[2].definitions[5].ex: He agreed to buy back the $130,000 machine, which he says is in good working order.
